htmlEmbed:
Memento10/30/2019

The service provides API access to the Wayback Machine Internet archive of over 150 billion web pages saved starting in 1996. The Memento protocol allows data-level access to the archive to allow retrieval of website content based on date-time specifications. API methods include TimeGate, which provides access to a site at points in time specified in its own page headers. The Memento API provides access as of a date specified in the request. The TimeMap API provides a download of archived content.

Management</a></div></div><div id="tabs-header-content"><div class="intro"><div class="api_description tabs-header_description"> The service provides API access to the Wayback Machine Internet archive of over 150 billion web pages saved starting in 1996. The Memento protocol allows data-level access to the archive to allow retrieval of website content based on date-time specifications.
API methods include TimeGate, which provides access to a site at points in time specified in its own page headers. The Memento API provides access as of a date specified in the request. The TimeMap API provides a download of archived content.</div><div class="clearboth"></div><div class="row"><div id="node-track" class="col-sm-12 col-md-6 col-lg-6"><a form-type-select form-group"> <label class="control-label" for="pw_version_style"><div class="pw_version_style_label">Choose Style<span class="pw-api-help-tooltip-wrapper" title="</p> <p><strong>REST</strong> is for a RESTful API. Dont worry. Were not that religious about what is RESTful and what isnt and neither are most of ProgrammableWebs users, especially when eventually, they will be able to power search for all RESTful APIs.</p> <p><strong>RPC (Remote Procedure Call)</strong> - This is primarily for Web services related APIs that typically involve GraphQL, SOAP and XML-RPC but weve seen others. If your API calls a known procedure on the Web service (other than using the supporting protocols built in verbs), pick this.</p> <p><strong>Streaming (formerly "Push/Streaming")</strong> is for situations where the API is involved in the streaming of data in one or both directions using something like Websockets, Webhooks, GraphQL Subscriptions, gRPC, etc. Think realtime. In streaming data use cases, it's usually some event (eg: a new price for a stock ticker) that triggers the streaming of the data. </p> <p><strong>Browser/Native</strong> is primarily reserved for locally accessible (on the local system), runtime, or OS APIs that are mashable into Web and mobile apps. For example, Javascript APIs found in the Web browser or a device specific API like one for the accelerometer in a smartphone. If you picked Browser or System/Embedded for API Type, pick this</p> <p><strong>Indirect </strong>is for an API that is not directly accessible from a programming environment, but rather is indirectly accessible through an SDK. For example, Evernotes API is based on Apache Thrift and it is not intended for direct access. Instead, it is accessible to developers via SDK. The reason we create this sort of stub entry for an API that technically doesnt exist is so that its easy for audience members to find their way to the relevant SDKs.</p> <p><strong>Email/Messaging/FTP </strong>Though they are not function-oriented APIs that a developer calls the way you might typically call an API, FTP, email (and other messaging systems) have historically been rigged by clever developers to emulate the role of an API. This class of API bears some resemblance to streaming, only it's usually not nearly as real-time. Popular implementations might involve transmission of a batch of data as a file (or as just the body of an email) to some inbox via Internet email (SMTP) or the File Transfer Protocol. If FTP, email, or a similar messaging system transports data between the API consumer and the API provider, pick this option. </p> <p><strong>Feed</strong> are a bit of kissing cousin to streaming APIs. Feeds typically involve a standard address (URI) that API consumers can periodically poll for updates in a way that it appears as though the data is being fed to them. Feeds typically don't require any authentication and rely on standard feed protocols like RSS or Atom (although some organizations will go to the trouble of setting up feeds based on a proprietary protocol). Pick this if your "API" involves a feed-type technology like RSS or Atom.</p>"><span class="pw_api_help_tooltip"><i class="glyphicon glyphicon-question-sign"></i></span></span></div></label><select autocomplete="off" class="pw_version_style-wrapper chosen-enable form-control form-select" id="pw_version_style" name="pw_version_style"><option value="25192" selected="selected">REST</option></select></div></div><div id="version_status_field" class="col-md-3 col-sm-3"><div class="form-item form-item-pw-version-style-status form-type-select form-group"> <label class="control-label" for="pw_version_style_status">Choose Version<span class="pw-api-help-tooltip-wrapper" title="<p>ProgrammableWeb now tracks multiple versions of each API across multiple architectural styles, essentially tracking those versions from beginning to end-of-life. While each status in the drop down should be self explanatory, here's some extra input to help you to decide.</p> <p>The <b>Pre-Release</b> version is one that's currently active but that has not yet ascended to being a recommended production version. It could be a beta or alpha release and may not be available to all developers.</p> <p>The <b>Recommended</b> version is an active, supported, production version of the API for a given architectural style that you prefer developers use in their applications. There can be multiple recommended versions when an API provider supports multiple architectural styles. For example, if the API is available as both a REST API and as an RPC-based API. But each of those versions should be entered as a separate entry into our directory.</p> <p> An <b>Active</b> version is also a supported, production version of an API. It's just not the recommended version. An API provider is very likely to have one or more active versions at the same time they have a different recommended version. This happens when the API provider decides to release a new version but is not ready to fully deprecate an older version at the same time.</p> <p>A <b>Retired</b> version is one where the API is still active (as with the previous state), but it is no longer supported through official channels. </p> <p>And finally, the <b>Deactivated</b> version is one whose endpoint is no longer accessible. ProgrammableWeb keep a record of this version for historical and research purposes.</p>"><span class="pw_api_help_tooltip"><i class="glyphicon glyphicon-question-sign"></i></span></span></label><select autocomplete="off" class="pw_version_style-wrapper chosen-enable form-control form-select" id="pw_version_style_status" readabilityObject.excerpt: The service provides API access to the Wayback Machine Internet archive of over 150 billion web pages saved starting in 1996. The Memento protocol allows data-level access to the archive to allow retrieval of website content based on date-time specifications. API methods include TimeGate, which provides access to a site at points in time specified in its own page headers. The Memento API provides access as of a date specified in the request. The TimeMap API provides a download of archived content.
